item.title: Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise
item.description:
Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise ðŸ”—

This article provides a comprehensive list of alien races featured in the Star Trek franchise, spanning from the original series to the latest installments. It emphasizes the significance of these alien encounters as a core element of the Star Trek narrative.

Key ðŸ”—

This section provides a key to the abbreviations used throughout the list to indicate the specific Star Trek media (TV series, films) in which each alien race appears. It includes the title, date, and medium for each abbreviation.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A.”

  • Aenar: A sub-species of Andorians from the planet Andoria, characterized by their light blue/white skin, near-blindness, and telepathic abilities. They are generally pacifistic. Key figures include Hemmer from Strange New Worlds and Talla, Shran’s daughter.
  • Andorian: A blue-skinned, antenna-bearing humanoid species from Andoria. They are depicted as a warrior race and were founding members of the United Federation of Planets.
  • Angosian: A species known for genetically and chemically engineering soldiers for the Tarsian Wars. These “super soldiers” were later confined to a penal settlement.
  • Antedean: An ichthyohumanoid species from Antede III that resembles fish and has a strong aversion to space travel.
  • Arcadian: A member of the United Federation of Planets with a representative on the Federation Council. They have large, round heads and distinctive hairstyles.
  • Arcturian: A species known for their clones, which have a melted skin appearance. They hail from the densely populated world Arcturus.
  • Axanar: The first extraterrestrial race befriended by Earth people aboard the NX-01 Enterprise. Captain Garth of Izar achieved a great victory on behalf of the Federation at the Battle of Axanar.

B ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “B.”

  • Bajoran: A humanoid species from the planet Bajor, characterized by nose ridges and deep spirituality. They worship The Prophets and were occupied by the Cardassians. Key locations include Bajor.
  • Ba’ku: A technologically advanced humanoid civilization that chose to abandon technology and live a simple life on an isolated planet with metaphasic radiation. Their aging process is significantly slowed. Key locations include The Briar Patch.
  • Benzite: A humanoid race from the planet Benzar, a member of the United Federation of Planets. They are known for their resistance to poisons and ability to digest almost any organic compound.
  • Betazoid: A telepathic humanoid species from the planet Betazed, a member of the United Federation of Planets. Deanna Troi is a prominent half-Betazoid character.
  • Bolian: Humanoids with blue skin and a ridge running from the back of their heads to their noses. They are active members of the Federation and known for crystal steel and the Bank of Bolius.
  • Borg: A pseudo-species of cybernetically enhanced individuals forming a collective consciousness. They assimilate other species to achieve perfection.
  • Breen: A mysterious race who joined the Dominion during the Dominion War.
  • Brikar: A large, rock-like species. Rok-Tahk from Star Trek: Prodigy is a notable example.

C ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “C.”

  • Cardassian: A species with ridges along their foreheads and necks, known for their military dictatorship and conflict with the United Federation of Planets. Key figures include Garak and Gul Dukat. Their homeworld is Cardassia Prime.
  • Chameloid: A race of shapeshifters. Martia is a notable example encountered by Kirk and McCoy.
  • Changeling: A race of fluid shapeshifters who founded the Dominion. Odo is a prominent Changeling character.

D ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “D.”

  • Douwd: Immortal energy beings with vast powers. Only one is known to exist, who committed xenocide against the Husnock.
  • Deltan: A humanoid species from the planet Delta IV, known for their strong sexual attraction. They take a vow of chastity upon joining Starfleet. Ilia and Melle are notable Deltans.

E ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “E.”

  • Edosian: A race of sentient tripedal beings. Lieutenant Arex was introduced in Star Trek: The Animated Series.
  • El-Aurian: A humanoid race known as “Listeners,” with long lifespans and a patient, wise demeanor. Their homeworld, El-Auria, was destroyed by the Borg. Guinan is a notable El-Aurian.

F ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “F.”

  • Ferengi: A species known for their focus on profit and the Rules of Acquisition. Quark is a notable Ferengi character. Their homeworld is Ferenginar.

G ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “G.”

  • Gorn: A violent, lizard-like species known for kidnapping people to serve as incubators for their eggs.

H ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “H.”

  • Hirogen: A violent Delta Quadrant species whose culture is based on hunting other sentient species.
  • Horta: Silicon-based life forms that eat rock on the planet Janus VI.

I ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “I.”

  • Illyrian: A species that practices genetic augmentation to adapt to various environments.

J ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “J.”

  • Jem’Hadar: Genetically engineered shock troops of the Dominion, bred for strength and loyalty to the Founders.

K ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “K.”

  • Kazon: A species introduced in Star Trek: Voyager. They are a nomadic species.
  • Kelpien: A species from the planet Kaminar, suppressed by the Ba’ul for generations. Commander Saru is a notable Kelpien.
  • Klingon: A warrior race with a strict honor code and ridged foreheads. Their homeworld is Kronos.
  • Kzinti: Feline warriors who had four wars with humanity.

L ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “L.”

  • Lanthanite: A long-lived species that has been secretly present on Earth since the 22nd century. Chief Engineer Pelia is a notable Lanthanite.

O ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “O.”

  • Ocampa: A humanoid species from the Delta Quadrant with a history of great mental feats.
  • Organian: Incorporeal energy creatures who render weapons inoperable to prevent conflict.
  • Orion: A green-skinned, humanoid species.

P ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “P.”

  • Pakled: A species that obtains technology from other races, often through trickery.

Q ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “Q.”

  • Q: Immortal, omnipotent beings who belong to the Q Continuum. One Q is particularly interested in humanity.

R ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “R.”

  • Romulan: A violent, treacherous offshoot of the Vulcans who rule the Romulan Empire. Their homeworld is Romulus.
  • Reman: A humanoid caste related to the Romulans, forced to live as enslaved under the Romulans and work in the dilithium mines on Remus.

S ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “S.”

  • Son’a: Former members of the Ba’ku who were exiled for embracing technology.
  • Species 8472: A powerful species from fluidic space that surpasses the Borg in combat prowess.

T ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “T.”

  • Talaxian: A species from the Delta Quadrant. Neelix is a notable Talaxian character.
  • Talosian: A race with the power of illusions from Talos IV.
  • Tellarite: A species known for their love of arguing and blunt speech. Their homeworld is Tellar Prime.
  • Tholian: A xenophobic, non-humanoid hermaphroditic species with a propensity for precision.
  • Tribble: A small, harmless species noted for their rapid reproduction.
  • Trill: A humanoid species where a small minority are joined with a long-lived symbiont. Jadzia Dax and Ezri Dax are notable Trill characters.

V ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “V.”

  • Vidiian: A species encountered in the Delta Quadrant

item.title: Allianceâ€“Union universe
item.description:
Allianceâ€“Union Universe ðŸ”—

The Allianceâ€“Union universe is a fictional setting created by C. J. Cherryh for her science fiction novels. It spans from the 21st century into the far future and focuses on humanity’s expansion into space. The universe is dominated by three major powers: Earth Company, the Alliance, and the Union.

Description ðŸ”—

This universe centers on humanity’s exploration and colonization of space, leading to the rise of three economic powers: Earth Company, the Alliance, and the Union. The Earth Company’s control is challenged during the Company Wars. The Union, based on the planet Cyteen, expands its territories using cloned humans called azi, leading to conflicts with the Alliance and Earth Company. Other series, such as The Faded Sun Trilogy, the Chanur novels, and Merovingen Nights, are linked within this universe, creating a larger narrative.

History ðŸ”—

Humanity’s initial expansion into space is facilitated by the Sol Corporation, later renamed the Earth Company, which finances the construction of space stations. These stations, built progressively farther from Earth, foster distinct cultural identities among stationers and merchanters. The discovery of Pell’s World in the Tau Ceti system disrupts the existing economic and political order, as it provides a habitable planet and supports alien life, the Hisa.

The development of faster-than-light (FTL) travel in 2248 prompts Earth to reassert its authority, leading to unrest and rebellion among the colonists. The Earth Company commissions the Company Fleet under Conrad Mazian to enforce its orders. In 2300, the colonists centered at Cyteen declare independence as the Union, augmenting their forces with genetically engineered clones (azi). The ensuing Company War sees fierce fighting between the Fleet and Union forces.

The conflict culminates at Pell’s World in 2352-2353. Merchanter families form the Alliance, a neutral power. Mazian refuses peace, leading to Signy Mallory’s defection to the Alliance with the ship Norway. Mazian’s coup attempt against Earth fails. The Alliance brokers a peace treaty, gaining a monopoly on interstellar commerce.

As the Mazianni threat diminishes, rivalry between the Alliance and Union intensifies. Tensions rise with the discovery of a secret Union colony on Gehenna. Within Union, political factions vie for power, while Ariane Emory pursues her own agenda.

Genre ðŸ”—

The works in this universe span various science fiction subgenres. Many stories set in space are considered space opera, while those on planets are planetary romances. Works like Cyteen and Downbelow Station are hard science fiction. The “Company Wars” novels and the Faded Sun trilogy are military science fiction. The Merovingen Nights series blends science fantasy with elements of sword and planet. Voyager in Night incorporates elements of horror fiction.

Books and Reading Order ðŸ”—

C. J. Cherryh has stated that the books can be read in any order, except for Heavy Time and Hellburner, which should be read in that order, and Cyteen and Regenesis, which are tightly linked. The novels in the Faded Sun trilogy, the Chanur series, and the Morgaine series are designed to be read in sequence. The Merovingen Nights series begins with Angel with the Sword and continues with the short story anthologies.

Major Characters ðŸ”—

Key figures in the Allianceâ€“Union universe include:

  • Pyanfar Chanur: Hani captain and leader of the Compact.
  • Sten Duncan: Alliance soldier who joins the Mri.
  • Ariane Emory-1 and Ariane Emory-2 PR: Scientist and her clone in the Union.
  • Damon Konstantin and Elene Quen: Leaders in the Merchanter Alliance.
  • Conrad Mazian: Commander of the Earth Company Fleet and later leader of the Mazianni.
  • Signy Mallory: Captain of the Norway who defects to the Alliance.
  • Elizabeth McGee: Union scientist.
  • James Robert Neihart: Captain of Finity’s End and negotiator for the Merchanter Alliance.
  • Kurt Morgan: Survivor of the Endymion.
  • Raen a Sul hant Meth-maren: Human mediator with the Majat.
  • Thorn: Human raised by the Shonunin.

Sentient Alien Species ðŸ”—

The Allianceâ€“Union universe features a diverse array of sentient alien species, each with unique cultures and characteristics. Some notable species include:

  • Amaut: Industrious humanoids.
  • Ahnit: Species appearing in Wave Without a Shore.
  • Caliban: Semi-reptilians on Gehenna.
  • Chi: Sticklike methane-breathers linked to the T’ca.
  • Elee: Humanoid, artistic species akin to the Mri.
  • Hani: Bipedal felines with a matriarchal society.
  • Hisa: Peaceful mammalians on Pell’s World.
  • Iduve: Dangerous, psychic humanoids.
  • Kallia: Thin, hollow-boned pacifists.
  • Kif: Long-snouted carnivores.
  • Knnn: Multi-legged methane-breathers.
  • Majat: Hive-mind insectoids.
  • Mahendo’sat: Political mammalians.
  • Mri: Humanoid, militaristic species.
  • Nemet: Humanoid species with a strict honor code.
  • Regul: Xenophobic species with differentiated juvenile and adult forms.
  • Stsho: Hermaphroditic, fragile species.
  • Sharrh: Advanced, aggressive species.
  • Shonunin: Bipedal mammalians with technology equivalent to 20th-century Earth.
  • Tc’a: Serpentine methane-breathers linked to the Chi.

Planets ðŸ”—

Several planets play significant roles in the Allianceâ€“Union universe:

Pell’s World ðŸ”—

Also known as Downbelow, Pell’s World orbits Tau Ceti and was discovered in 2093. It is the first planet with an advanced ecosystem and intelligent extraterrestrial life (the Hisa). Pell Station orbits the planet.

Gehenna ðŸ”—

Located in the Zeta Reticuli system, Gehenna is home to the calibans. It was secretly colonized by the Union and then abandoned.

Cyteen ðŸ”—

Cyteen is a planet in Union territory with a toxic atmosphere. It required terraforming and the establishment of enclaves. It is the source of the rejuvenation drug.

Merovin ðŸ”—

Merovin is an isolated planet with backward technology due to poor interstellar relations with the Sharrh.

Technologies ðŸ”—

Key technologies in the Allianceâ€“Union universe include:

  • Jump Drive: Allows faster-than-light travel.
  • Rejuv: A life-extension drug derived from Cyteen.
  • Cloning: Used extensively in the Union to create azi.
  • Tape: Subliminal conditioning and information transfer.
  • Terraforming: Used to make areas of Cyteen suitable for Earth-based life.

Society ðŸ”—

A key aspect of the Allianceâ€“Union universe is the divergence of attitudes among planet-dwellers, stationers, and spacers. Planet dwellers have concerns similar to those of 21st-century people. Stationers are cautious due to the fragility of their environment. Spacers have an insular worldview due to the effects of jump. In the Union, there is a division between citizens and azi.

Mazianni ðŸ”—

The Mazianni are the military starships and crews loyal to Conrad Mazian after he renounces allegiance to Earth. They engage in guerrilla warfare and prey on merchant ships.

Songs ðŸ”—

C. J. Cherryh wrote songs about the station trade, which were recorded by Leslie Fish and released on the album Finity’s End.

Critical Reception ðŸ”—

John Clute called the Allianceâ€“Union universe Cherryh’s “central achievement.” M. Keith Booker described it as “so far-reaching that its overall outlines remain unclear and continue to develop.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mri_(fictional_alien_species)

The Allianceâ€“Union universe is a fictional setting created by C. J. Cherryh for her science fiction novels. It spans from the 21st century into the far future and centers on humanity’s expansion into space. The universe is dominated by three major powers: Earth Company, the Alliance, and the Union.

Description ðŸ”—

This section introduces the core concept of the Alliance-Union universe as a future history spanning millennia, focusing on humanity’s exploration and colonization of space. It highlights the emergence of three major economic powers: Earth Company, the Alliance (a confederation of interstellar trade merchants), and the Union (a breakaway government based on Cyteen). The section also mentions the Company Wars, the Union’s use of cloned humans called azi, and the interconnectedness of Cherryh’s various series within this universe, forming a “megatext.”

History ðŸ”—

This section details the historical timeline of the Alliance-Union universe, starting with the establishment of space stations by the Earth Company. It covers the development of distinct cultural identities among stationers and merchanters, the discovery of Pell’s World (a planet hospitable to humans and home to the Hisa), and the invention of faster-than-light (FTL) travel. The section describes the Company Wars between Earth and the Union, the rise of Conrad Mazian and the Company Fleet, the formation of the Alliance as a neutral power, and the subsequent rivalry between the Alliance and the Union. Key events include the conflict at Pell Station (described in Downbelow Station) and the emergence of Ariane Emory as a political leader within the Union.

Genre ðŸ”—

This section categorizes the various works within the Alliance-Union universe by genre. It identifies elements of space opera, planetary romance, hard science fiction, military science fiction, science fantasy, and horror fiction. Specific works are mentioned as examples of each genre, such as Cyteen and Downbelow Station as hard science fiction, the Faded Sun trilogy as military science fiction, and the Merovingen Nights series as science fantasy.

Books and Reading Order ðŸ”—

This section provides guidance on the order in which to read the books set in the Alliance-Union universe. It notes that most books can be read in any order, with two exceptions: Heavy Time and Hellburner should be read in that order, as should Cyteen and Regenesis. The section also advises reading the novels within the Faded Sun, Chanur, and Morgaine series in sequence.

Major Characters ðŸ”—

This section lists and describes several key characters in the Alliance-Union universe. These include Pyanfar Chanur (Hani captain and leader of the Compact), Sten Duncan (Alliance soldier who joins the Mri), Ariane Emory (Union scientist and administrator), Damon Konstantin and Elene Quen (leaders of the Merchanter Alliance), Conrad Mazian (commander of the Earth Company Fleet), Signy Mallory (captain of the Norway), Elizabeth McGee (Union scientist), James Robert Neihart (captain of Finity’s End), Kurt Morgan (crewman of the Endymion), Raen a Sul hant Meth-maren (human mediator with the Majat), and Thorn (human raised by the Shonunin).

Sentient Alien Species ðŸ”—

This section provides a table listing various sentient alien species encountered in the Alliance-Union universe. The table includes the species name, home system, home planet, the works in which they appear, and brief notes about their characteristics. Some of the species listed are the Amaut, Ahnit, Caliban, Chi, Elee, Hani, Hisa, Iduve, Kallia, Kif, Knnn, Majat, Mahendo’sat, Mri, Nemet, Regul, Stsho, Sharrh, Shonunin, and Tc’a.

Planets ðŸ”—

This section describes several key planets within the Alliance-Union universe.

Pell’s World ðŸ”—

Pell’s World, orbiting Tau Ceti, is the first planet discovered with an advanced ecosystem and intelligent extraterrestrial life (the Hisa). Its discovery sparked moral and policy debates on Earth and disrupted the balance of power, contributing to the Company Wars. Pell Station orbits the planet.

Gehenna ðŸ”—

Gehenna, in the Zeta Reticuli system, is home to the calibans. Secretly colonized by the Union and then abandoned, it became a source of conflict between the Alliance and the Union.

Cyteen ðŸ”—

Cyteen, deep in Union territory, required terraforming due to its toxic atmosphere. It is the source of the rejuvenation drug and the center of azi research and development.

Merovin ðŸ”—

Merovin is isolated and technologically backward due to poor interstellar relations with the Sharrh.

Technologies ðŸ”—

This section outlines the key technologies present in the Alliance-Union universe. These include the jump drive (allowing faster-than-light travel), rejuv (a life-extension drug), human cloning (particularly the creation of azi), tape (subliminal conditioning and information transfer), and terraforming technologies.

Society ðŸ”—

This section discusses the societal structures and attitudes within the Alliance-Union universe. It highlights the divergence of attitudes between planet-dwellers, space station-dwellers, and starship crews. It also describes the cultural and psychological division between unengineered citizens and azi in the Union.

Mazianni ðŸ”—

This section defines the Mazianni as the military starships and crews loyal to Conrad Mazian after he renounces allegiance to Earth. It describes their origins as the Earth Company Fleet, their role in the Company War, Mazian’s rebellion, and their subsequent guerrilla warfare against the major powers.

Songs ðŸ”—

This section mentions a collection of songs written by C. J. Cherryh about the station trade in the Alliance-Union universe, which were recorded by filk musician Leslie Fish and released on the album Finity’s End.

Critical Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception of the Alliance-Union universe. John Clute calls it Cherryh’s “central achievement,” noting its rough edges but the impression of a larger, yet-to-be-revealed history. M. Keith Booker describes it as “so far-reaching that its overall outlines remain unclear and continue to develop.”
